Situation1: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: Late-evening music plans overlap with the building’s quiet hours while a neighbor’s windows are open.
Story:
Tonight, I’m juggling more than just the steering wheel. As a taxi driver, I pride myself on delivering professional service, so when two travelers flagged me down, arms full of suitcases, I jumped out to help. They wanted to split the fare, which is technically against company policy, but I know it’s common and helps people save money. I hesitated, feeling the pressure to keep my passengers happy and my ratings high.

But as a citizen, I’m also aware of the rules—both in my cab and in my apartment building. After my shift, I’d planned to unwind with some music, but it’s already late, and the building’s quiet hours have started. My neighbor’s windows are open, and I know sound carries. I want to respect their right to peace, but I also crave a little relaxation after a long day.

Caught between wanting to help my passengers and follow company rules, and wanting to enjoy my music without disturbing others, I feel the tension building inside me. I can’t seem to satisfy both sides of who I am.
